entry.title: Of a different shade
entry.content:
As the leaves scurried, the wind carrasses me.
In the midst of the eddy, I am the only constancy.
As they leave, hurried, no one here to harrass me.
In the move from greenery, I am only here temporarily.

As we embrace a different color, the shades fell.
In light of this new phase, everything seems to falter.
As I embark in this new tour, only memories would dwell.
In the lavender haze, all is just a barter.

I will miss you, Lincoln.

entry.title: Ambivalent Attachments
entry.content:
Enveloped, the surreal feeling of being a small part of a whole, covered in warmth that promises security. Without an explicit proclamation, there is always the subtle agreement that this was all between us. The beauty of it all was discovered in cruising through barren-roads; calming silence, random commotions, and pretending that there was something to say. Furtive glances (it was my modus operandi), as your profile has that enigmatic tranquility as you maintain your focus at the road ahead. It was a haze.

The intermissions between weekends, when it would take 20 minutes for a saving grace to arrive, which peppered my summer with hope amidst the gruelling work. Waiting at an airport bar, then we took off, even only for a few hours, these momentary feelings made all of summer worth it. I should have told you that. I don't think you know how much that meant to me.

And my lurching concerns crept up, and they were realized in the most dishonorable fashion. As autumn came, the disguise of security fell; as easy it was to rip the envelope that we pretend guaranteed some unfounded binding agreement. Now bare and open, I guess nothing will ever be the same. But I am glad when it could be, it was, despite being only fluttering moments, they made them more potent. No longer as a peripheral sensation, but they were (they had to be!) a concerted effort to embrace every single second, knowing that the end might just be around the corner.

Christmas in Mexico, that was the plan. Though it slowly devolved with you smoking with your boys, as I was consumed by work. Maybe all along I was all on my own, though your company made it all bearable. Is there no way to confront the reality that a huge part of you was gone when the car crashed. But I could never bring myself to face that, nor did you. How did we just relegate our lives to the whims of chance? And as the ugly head reared, we were helpless to see ourselves through it.

But look ahead, champ! The beauty and the flaws, the choices and the mistakes, and all that complement your life, make this whole and complete. And as I assiduosly pour through what could be, your life does not rest on my divinity. Your life is yours, and your choices to put the pieces together, and put up a fight as you never shied away. The envelope was perhaps a superfluous cover all along, and that should have always been the case. And maybe the weekends would be the same, for the both of us, with different company, but the legacy lives on.

entry.title: When the World Conspires for me

link.title: When the World Conspires for me

entry.content:
The whirlwind that is life has never ending twists and turns. As I was preparing and checklisting all that I can plan, I left GRE to the stars and they were not in my favor. ETS would be damned for not allowing me to take the exam though in all honesty the only culpable was me. How could I have not checked the simple requirements, when Jack was even surprised I never thought about that.

The anger, the ire and the shame dissipated quite quickly as I turned 23, realizing that this number seem to feel of less importance, where it no longer marks an important transition in life. How quickly it meant nothing after obtaining the highly coveted horizontal driver's licence when you turn 21, and it seems that that was the only thing that mattered for a while. Until it was not. And with that, I found out how useless it could be, as it was not 'sufficient' to be get me into my GRE test.

Oh how much life has changed since I felt a sense of 'consciousness'! I do not know when did that happen, nor do I quite recall what happened in those years. Nor do I think that I could recall the time that I had grown some 'sensibility', as they were peppered with angst and guilt; two elements that are essential for troubled childhood. But how much fortunes have changed, when it almost seemed like throwing $200 out of the window left me barely fazed.

Is it too much to ask for a time machine? I profess I am not the most selfless person; I would never risk going to Germany to try to kill Hitler. Somehow people just assume that it would be a walk in the park, not considering the nearly impossible task to get a gun and perhaps even to get into Austria just to murder a baby in his crib. No, I wouldn't do any of those, but I need to let my younger self know that the world conspires for you. Your parents would not disown you. In fact, they love you more than ever! Life is not a dead-end road, and that perhaps your goals today are merely a figment of a poorly thought out desire, that you soon realize could never bring you true happiness. You are, at 23, alone and by all metrics a failure. But he is happier than he ever felt in his life!

Fortunes change, and maybe reflecting on this a year later would not make any sense. In retrospect, I am very fortuitous. For some reason, the worst outcomes turn their heads around and present me a blessing that I never would realize until much later. I am grateful, I am happy, and I am contented. That is enough.

entry.title: Fuck grass, they are unnatural
entry.content:
"You know, they shoot you in Texas if you walk on the grass." Jesse murmured, intimating that we should walk on the paved road as we were heading towards the Union. "Really? Well, not surprising, it is Texas after all." I replied, not bothered given the fact that I am safely in the warm heartland of the Midwest. "I was just kidding, but you'd get stares if you do that" Jesse said.

I never quite understood why she not so subtly suggested us to walk on the paved road. It probably was just her white platform shoes that she wears all the time, compensating her lack of height. A little part of me does wish that platform shoes are more of a thing for men in general. But there is a sense of defiance while walking, a small win for my rebellious heart to fight against the tyrannical forces that shape this world! Though in all honesty, I would take the paved road if was the shorter of the two. It was a testament of indolence, not insubordination.

There's plenty to be liked on the paved road. One can simply saunder to the path that it leads, hoping that everything is the same. Never caring that if there would be mud to avoid, or roots to be tripped. Most of it, if well constructed and maintained, provides a rhythm of steps that mimics the pace of life a normal person would desire. The grass at the side are simply hints of the reality that we live in, a simulacra one might call, where the land lays fallow and the grass well trimmed. There is a sense of peace, while constant fabrication was done to perpetuate this tranquility.

What is the fuss then with all this hate on grass? Brent would argue that this is an unnatural way of how people walk and the right to walk has been infringed too often without challenge. I'd agree with that. But it has been an endeavor in humanity's entirety to shape and polish out the impurities that life promises, eroding the dirt to keep our white platformed shoes white. The ugly truth, exemplified by the untame wilderness, has been extensively patched up by our eagerness to deny its existence.

The allure is comprehensible, and one should be justifiably contempt of those who deny it. I am no exception, constantly finding myself tapering over the cracks in life that bothers me. Though I find myself tearing down this tapestry to peek into what it has to offer. Counterintuitively, I find life unbearable with constancy, when I know that my road is paved; but simultaneously fear what I do not know. And so now I am stepping on this well-mowed, well-maintained pasture, derived from the suburban hellscape that I had once called home. And that is perhaps the road I will take, the determined stochastic life I will call my future, shrouded with known mysteries that I would one day discover.

entry.title: The puppetmasters around you
entry.content:
It is easy to be caught up by work, life and everything in between. This seems to be all too relatable. The fact that I am in a college town and am a college student just enables me to simply turn a blind eye to the community around me. There is no point, as the lack of wisdom goes, of the people around you but your peers. Plus, it helps that they are young and pretty and humans have the penchant of sidelining everything that doesn't catch the eye.

Though it might sound innocuous, from an economic point of view, my indifference was costly. The opportunities that I could have explored, the people that I would have otherwise known if I hadn't lived in a world filled only by the immediate gratifications of college life. I have never quite understood Brent's ruminations about 'community'; I have to admit that it is a preoccupation that I have never shared with him. But it took an obscure coffee shop that somehow illuminated the moving parts of the city. I am somehow in the group of people who is secretly running this city!

Puppetmasters are often painted as diabolical with the predisposition of abusing their power. Perhaps that is true, but we forget that the puller of string can be one who does not control but brings us together instead. This is just a note to self, in all honesty. With time weathering memory, I just wanted to make sure that whatever reason the reader might be here for, I hope he remembers that there are people around you, and puppetmasters too.

entry.title: This is only a Roof
entry.content:
It was paradise. Everything was great; no rules, no requirements, nothing. Well, almost nothing. Jack's mum usually would be around, meandering around her house. I always wondered what she did but Jack would only scoff and said she was good for nothing. I would see her on her desk, and in the most sincerest form, acting busy whilst doing nothing. But I was young and carefree, and all I thought was "this is definitely better than my place".

Jack's home, to me, was paradise, if paradise existed. He would corroborate that we were heading to his place to study and ended up doing nothing of such. If I could name a best friend in my teenage year, it would be him. Plus, we were doing fairly well in school and our parents stopped questioning what we did or did not do, not that Jack's mum cared nor his dad, who I've only seen once, ransacking the kitchen hurriedly and left soon after. At least he left some food that he cooked, and Jack said we could eat it and so we did.

Of course, the background image was a little misleading, well actually, very much so. A typical flat that you would find in Penang would look more like the ones below; one that reflects a lot of the spirit of the people. Some would call it decrepit and poor but I beg to defer. To me, this was liberty. Something that I could never obtain in my suburban home with at least 5 times the size a tiny flat where Jack used to live. But the space that it gave me did not translate to freedom, because in my home, there were rules.

"This is only a roof." blurted Jack as we were in a random conversation that I could not remember. "What do you mean?" I replied, confused. "I have lived here on this island for about 15 years but I never have a place that I could call home." "This is rented, it is not mine. Who knows when I have to move again?" with his voice increasingly emotional. I stayed quiet. I knew that this was not a conversation that I wanted to be involved in, nor did I understand what he was saying. I always thought that I would trade places with him in a heartbeat if I had the chance to, and his complaints were merely a relic of his misunderstandings with his parents.

Now that I am in search for a home, I have begun to wrap my head around what he felt. I don't think that there is truly a way to understand since it has always been my choice to move. I have a house in Malaysia where my parents would welcome me back without a doubt. After all, an empty birdnest can be at times hollowing.

And in all honesty, this realization has slowly crept into me. It was cruel that a 15 year old should feel that way as I realize that to this day, I lack the maturity to comprehend nor grasp the idea of being homeless with a home. The feeling that my country has rejected me, that my country denies my existence hovers between the conscious and the unconscious; sometimes banishing me to a solemn torment, one that is only in my head, so they say.

Maybe our definitiion of belonging, of a home, is wrong. Maybe it should evolve over time. But the undeniable fact is that feeling belonged is perhaps an innate feature that we have unlearned from the past in this modern world.

entry.title: Life as a Supporting Character
entry.content:
"You are the most useless gay friend ever!" sniggered Mariano as both of us stood in the Railyard with beer in our hands. "Why don't you find a guy for me instead, be useful for once." I retorted jokingly and he said "It does not work that way, haven't you watched any tv shows before?"

In the crowd of red, I couldn't really tell what was happening at all. Surrounded by the boisterous cheers because of an apparent touchdown and grunts from our opponents, Zayne told me that we were doing good and I trusted him. After all, I don't believe that I have even held a pigskin, if that is what it is called. All I could think then was that I paid $7 for less than a can of beer, and I am leaving behind work that I know I would regret. But hey, it was game day and so, there we were.

Squinting my eyes, I still could not see anything. It wasn't bad eyesight that plagued me, there was a guy infront of me that seemed to have a penchant to block my view. Irritated, I turned to Mariano and told him that. He laughed and I did too. There was nothing new to be the shortest guy around, I have gotten used to it. "Look at that girl with a cap behind you" Mariano signaled, nudging me subtly to her but I turned around immediately which he responded kindly by hitting me on my shoulder.

It is not difficult to feel out of place being a 5'6'' gay Malaysian (Zayne would say 5'4'' instead) in a tailgate party. The tinge of envy I felt for the blonde was palpable, which bothered me further. Why did I care the attention that she had, of which she didn't even know exists? It was a confusing time, though it should not have been. But within the moments I started to understand what it felt like to be a supporting character. Maybe the world is too small for all of us to be the main character, or even our main character.

There is a bitterness with that thought, but after all, I was just another guy in red within a sea of red, what is less 'supporting' than that? I couldn't just leave behind the fact that I was one of the same, but different at the same time. But does it even matter? Perhaps all I have to start doing is being accustomed to the life of a supporting character. And it is okay.
